content: Flu vaccine has run out; Florida's okay for now

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td blockquote h4 span
content: Two makers of shots say their 83-million doses of vaccine are gone and more can't be ready before the end of flu season.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font span
content: Franca Sweaney, gets her flu shot Friday at Tropicana Field as Doug Yeates, 10, and Jessika Wethington, 11, watch.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: ST. PETERSBURG - The cars stretched from the edge of the Tropicana Field parking lot to the main entrance Friday morning. Hundreds of people, concerned that this winter's flu season could be the worst in years, were getting drive-through vaccinations.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Friday afternoon, two makers of flu shots announced they have run out of vaccine and will not be able to meet the late surge in demand. The companies, Chrion and Aventis Pasteur, made about 83-million doses of the injected vaccine, which ordinarily would be enough to take care of U.S. demand.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "Because of the recent outbreak, we've seen an unprecedented surge of vaccine orders late in the season," said Len Lavenda, an Aventis spokesman. "As a result, we have now shipped all our available supplies."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Florida is not suffering a vaccine shortage, state Health Secretary John Agwunobi said during a conference call with reporters Friday evening. And although flu activity has been early and harsh in some Western states this year, so far in Florida, it is about the same as the previous three or four years, he said. "It actually has been a little lower than expected," Agwunobi said. "But it's prudent that we prepare."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Agwunobi's office is conducting inventories of all county health departments and also trying to gauge how much vaccine is available in the private sector. The vast majority of vaccinations, Agwunobi said, are given through private physicians, hospitals and chain drugstores.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "Those who need to get vaccinated will get vaccinated," Agwunobi said, but he said that those most vulnerable, including children, the elderly and the chronically ill, should get vaccine first.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Agwunobi said there were about 300 flu cases reported statewide last week, with no deaths since the flu season began.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "But we are early - just the ninth week."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: The vaccine makers said they cannot make more vaccine this year because the process takes four months. By that time, the flu season would be over.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Health officials in Pinellas County said they have enough vaccine for the immediate future. "Right now, we're not worried too much," said Diana Jordan, a registered nurse who oversees communicable disease surveillance for the county health department. "But I suspect there will be an increased demand."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: In Hillsborough, the supply is stretched a bit thinner.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "We have some, but not an unlimited supply," said Cindy Hardy, immunization program manager for the Hillsborough County Health Department. "Right now, some of our locations don't have any vaccine, so we're directing people to the sites where it is.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "We've already doubled the amount we usually give, and it's only early December.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "It's just a shame that people waited so long this year," Hardy said. "If they got their shots on a regular basis in October or November, we wouldn't be in the panic we're in now."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: The CDC said it is not unusual for supplies to run short this time of year when health care providers usually stop giving vaccinations. A big shortage in November of 2000 happened because of problems in making the vaccine that year.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: This year, the scramble for flu shots began in earnest last month, when researchers said they expected a higher flu death toll than usual this winter. In a typical year, 36,000 Americans die and more than 114,000 are hospitalized because of the influenza virus.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: But the flu season usually stretches from October to May, peaking in December and January. And this year, cases were reported in some Western states as early as September. The flu has been blamed for the deaths of at least six children in Colorado, three in Texas and one each in Oklahoma and New Mexico.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Dr. Tim Uyeki, medical epidemiologist for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said the number of children getting seriously ill and dying worries the agency. Typically, he said, "there may be a lot of illness among children, but deaths usually occur among elderly people."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: The flu is an infection of the respiratory tract caused by the influenza virus. It is typically characterized by headache, fever, a severe cough, sore throat, muscle aches, runny or stuffy nose, and often, extreme fatigue.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Health experts suggest receiving the vaccination by early December because it takes up to two weeks before the vaccination becomes effective.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Most of the outbreak this fall has been a strain called A-Fujian-H3N2, which was not selected for this year's flu vaccine, according to the CDC. Experts say the strain is closely related to the strain the vaccine targets, A-Panama-H3N2.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "The strain changes every year, so it's very intelligent guesswork by the CDC as to which strain is going to hit," said Linda Hoffmeister, infection control nurse for St. Anthony's Hospital.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Health experts say the vast majority of the millions of Americans who get the flu will recover.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: But they also stress that the Tampa Bay area is more vulnerable than other parts of the country because of the area's large number of elderly people and because it is a prime tourist destination.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Health care providers from St. Anthony's, Morton Plant and other area hospitals in the BayCare Health System began giving the $15 flu vaccinations at Tropicana Field at 7:30 a.m. Friday. By the noon cutoff time, they had administered more than 400 shots. And people were still pulling in line.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "This is way more than we've ever had before," said Barbara Baker, a program coordinator at St. Anthony's. "Most people say they heard it's going to be a rough year."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: On Thursday alone, Doctor's Walk-In Clinic administered 408 shots at its eight Hillsborough and north Pinellas locations.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "That's at least 30 percent more shots than we give this time of year," said Barbara Chronik, the clinic's operations manager. "We think we have a pretty good supply of vaccine for the weekend. Just this week we ordered 1,000 more doses."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Back at Tropicana Field, Steve and Jessica O'Brien of St. Petersburg took time off work to sit in their red Nissan 300 ZX and wait for their shots. They, too, had heard the flu season was going to be bad.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: "We'll probably get sick before we get the shots," Steve O'Brien, 33, said with a smirk. "We've been waiting almost an hour and a half. But I've been hospitalized from the flu before, and I'm not going through that again."

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: - Information from the Associated Press was used in this report.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font b span
content: Some questions and answers about flu

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Q: Will I be able to get a flu shot?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: A: That depends on demand. There have been shortages in some hard-hit areas. The largest vaccine makers have distributed all the vaccine they produced - 83-million doses - and they can't make any more quickly.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Q: Who needs the flu shot most?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: A: People 50 and older, infants and toddlers, people with asthma, diabetes, chronic heart or lung disease and weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV; and women who will be more than three months pregnant during the flu season.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Q: Several children have died from the flu. Are they considered more at risk for this year's flu strain?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: A: Disease experts are concerned that so many children seem to be affected, but they say they have too little information to consider them at greater risk for the flu.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Q: Because there may not be enough flu shots to go around, what should I do if I'm healthy?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: A: Disease doctors are recommending the new FluMist nasal spray; it's more expensive, but there are ample supplies of it for use by healthy people ages 5-49.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Q: Can I get the flu even though I got a flu shot this year?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: A: Yes, but it can make the symptoms milder and prevent deadly complications. Typically, the flu shot protects between 70 and 90 percent of healthy people. The elderly are more susceptible.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: The power of the flu shot also depends on how well it matches the flu virus in circulation. The current Fujian flu strain affecting most people is not the strain in this year's flu shot. But disease experts say it is a close enough match that considerable protection should be provided.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: - Sources: AP, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
